## Ph.D. Dissertation Colloquium

Date: May 22, 2025
<br>
Location: 10-401, MIT

This presentation outlined the two-year research plan for my doctoral dissertation, building upon the Sidewalk Ballet project.

The dissertation consists of two main phases. In the first phase, I developed a three-step pipeline to detect social groups in sidewalk scenes using computer vision and large language models. In the second phase, I will integrate these social interaction findings with additional street-level features to construct a set of Human Activity and Interaction (HAI) indices. These indices aim to support both upstream and downstream applications in urban design research.

All members of my dissertation committee attended the colloquium: Prof. Andres Sevtsuk, Prof. Jinhua Zhao, and Prof. Lawrence Vale. The external reviewer was Prof. Albert Saiz.

:::

## Exploring the Challenges of Humanity's Last Exam

::::: {.columns}
:::: {.column width="70%"}
::: {.callout-note}
## Final Presentation @ HLE Exploration

Date: Aug 20, 2025
<br>
Location: Lab 126 Sunnyvale, CA

This presentation introduces my analysis of the Humanity’s Last Exam (HLE) benchmark, a 2,500-question dataset spanning STEM, medicine, and humanities. I discussed the dataset’s quality issues, small-model performance, and reasoning behaviors. The work highlights how current distilled models (e.g., Qwen3 series) perform under strict evaluation and presents a framework to analyze reasoning errors and recurring problem-solving strategies.

:::

## Urban Big Data in China

::::: {.columns}
:::: {.column width="70%"}
::: {.callout-note}
## Panel Talk @ 11.001 Intro to Urban Design and Development

Date: May 8, 2024
<br>
Location: 4-370, Massachusetts Institute of Technology

This presentation explores my entrepreneurship journey, focusing on urban big data analytics in China. Specifically, I discuss four distinct types of data: open data, web-crawled data, purchased data, and geo-tagged visual data. For each category, I describe 2-3 datasets that I have worked with and detail specific research questions and case studies associated with them.
:::

## Guest Talk @ ESCAP, UN 2019

Date: Jul 25, 2019
<br>
Location: Jakarta, Indonesia

My team is invited as a representative of FCIC to participate in the project initiation meeting on "Improving the Use and Sharing of Geospatial Information to Promote Resilient and Sustainable Development." This event, hosted by the United Nations Economic and Social Commission for Asia and the Pacific (UN-ESCAP) and organized by the Indonesian National Institute of Aeronautics and Space (LAPAN). During this meeting, we engaged in vibrant discussions with representatives from Cambodia, Mongolia, Thailand, Kyrgyzstan, Indonesia, and experts from research institutions such as The Chinese University of Hong Kong, the Remote Sensing Institute of the Chinese Academy of Sciences, and the City University of Macau.

:::
